repnme.cdata!:
Kenya -  Lake Victoria Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lake Victoria Environmental
            Management Project for Kenya rated as follows: the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: The
            project provided rich experience and lessons derived from
            successes and disappointments in implementation. As is
            fitting for a project supporting acquisition of knowledge,
            many of the lessons learned are technical in nature.
            Interlinked national projects are vulnerable to failure of
            one of the partners, and must build in peer review and
            assistance, and safeguards in the event that these fail.
            Scientific research must be targeted, provide usable
            information for management decisions and be widely
            accessible. Regional projects necessitate greater emphasis
            on clarity of project objectives, monitorable frameworks, at
            multiple levels, and adequate mechanisms for governance. The
            Basin perspective is critical to address the key
            environmental issues of Lake Victoria. Capacity Building has
            to address both current and projected gaps. Implementation
            in the future can be undertaken through governmental
            structures. Environmental benefits must be strongly linked
            to improved livelihoods for local people and communities.
            Good education of the public and parliamentarians is
            critical for long term sustainability and success.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Lake Victoria Environmental
            Management Project : management report and recommendation in
            response to the Inspection Panel Investigation report

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the management response to the
            Inspection Panel's investigation report upon the Lake
            Victoria Environmental Management Project, specifically,
            concerning the design, and implementation of the water
            hyacinth management component of the Project in Kenya, a
            small-scale experimental pilot, for fast removal of water
            hyacinth to alleviate blockage of fish landing sites, ports,
            and sensitive areas in the lake. While the Inspection Panel
            concludes that Management is in compliance with operational
            environmental guidelines, it is not however, in full
            compliance with meeting the overall nature of the
            Operational Directive, i.e., adequate consultations with
            affected groups, and nongovernmental organizations.
            Management's recommended actions include: continuing
            the program of monitoring the area where water hyacinth
            chopping took place, to take action regarding adverse
            outcomes; continue a sustained, vigilant surveillance, and
            monitoring the spread of water hyacinth; follow-up on the
            five measures, aimed at strengthening commitment to
            increased community participation; and, sustain the practice
            of executive directors of the project's three
            countries' Project Management Unit, in participating in
            supervision activities. Consideration by the Executive
            Directors of the Board, will be scheduled on a date to be determined.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Lake Victoria Environmental
            Management Project : Inspection Panel Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Inspection Panel Report and findings
            on the Lake Victoria Environmental Management Project is a
            five year program aimed at the rehabilitation of the Lake
            Victoria ecosystem for the benefit of the people that live
            in the area.. Over-fishing and oxygen depletion at lower
            depths threaten fisheries and biodiversity. Algae blooms
            have developed on the surface and water hyacinth have begun
            to choke waterways and landings. The Lake Victoria
            Environmental Management Project (LVEMP) planned to reverse
            the deterioration of the aquatic resources and the
            environmental conditions of the lake's ecosystem and
            the maximize the sustainable benefits to the surrounding
            communities. A Request was submitted by Resources Conflict
            Institute (RECONCILE), a Kenyan non-governmental
            organization, that the proposed use of a mechanical method
            of shredding water hyacinth and letting it sink to the
            bottom of the lake would result in ecological and
            environmental degradation which, in turn, would adversely
            affect communities living on the shores of Lake Victoria.
            After evaluating the request and examining the claims, the
            Panel determined that the water hyacinth was a major threat
            to the livelihood of surrounding communities and that the
            possible polluting affects of decaying shredded hyacinths
            was convincing. The Panel finds that program of shredding
            the water hyacinths has been beneficial to the majority of
            inhabitants and finds that the Bank is in compliance with
            their own regulations. Other findings note that alternatives
            to the mechanical shredders were considered and that
            although there is no clear path as to how the shredding
            operations will continue there is no evidence to imply that
            the shredding process will not be unsustainable in view of cost.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Lake Victoria Environmental
            Management Project : Inspection Panel Report and Recommendation

abstracts.cdata!:
The Report and Recommendation for the
            Lake Victoria Environmental Management Project in Kenya
            examines the Request made and summarizes the project. The
            Requestors claim that the proposed use of a mechanical
            method of shredding water hyacinth and letting it sink to
            the bottom of the Lake will result in ecological decay and
            environmental degradation that, in turn, will adversely
            affect communities living on the shores at the Nyanza Gulf.
            These communities depend directly on the Lake for their
            livelihoods, since the Gulf is home to fresh water fish and
            the source of water for domestic use and these, and the
            ecosystem, will be endangered by the resulting pollution.
            Management feels that this is a misunderstanding in that the
            proposed method is only a pilot project and is not a means
            to solve the hyacinth problem. Measures are being taken to
            insure more community involvement in the project and to
            raise awareness of activities. The Panel feels that there
            are conflicting issues and responses in the Request and the
            Response and that an investigation would better enable a
            conclusion.  Request for Inspection and Management Response
            are available in Annexes.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda - Lake Victoria
            Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Lake Victoria
            Environmental Management Project are to: a) maximize the
            sustainable benefits to riparian communities from using
            resources within the basin to generate food, employment and
            income, supply safe water, and sustain a disease-free
            environment; and b) conserve biodiversity and genetic
            resources for the benefit of the riparian communities and
            the global community. A further project objective is to
            harmonize national management programs in order to achieve,
            to the maximum extent possible, the reversal of increasing
            environmental degradation. This project has eight
            components. They include: 1) fisheries management; 2)
            fisheries research; 3) fisheries extension, policies, and
            laws; 4) water hyacinth control; 5) water quality
            monitoring; 6) industrial and municipal waste management; 7)
            land use and wetland management; and 8) policy and
            institutional framework.

Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda - Lake Victoria
            Environmental Management Project
